H0.text: 2Sn + 4HNO₃ → SnO₂ + 4NO₂ + H₂O demonstrates the conservation of matter, as shown by the chemical equation.

H1.text: I₂ + 5 Cl₂ + 6 H₂O → 2 HIO₃ + 10 HCl demonstrates the conservation of matter by showing that the total number of atoms of each element is the same on both sides of the equation.

H2.text: Cl + 4Na → 4NaCl demonstrates the conservation of matter by showing that the number of atoms of each element is the same on both sides of the chemical equation.

H3.text: 4P + 5HNO₃ → 5NO + 3H₃PO₄ is the chemical equation that demonstrates the conservation of matter.

A4.text: the principle implies that during a chemical reaction the total mass of the reactants is equal to the total mass of the products

A5.text: the total mass of the reactants, or starting materials, must be equal to the mass of the products

A6.text: It is wise to check that the final equation is balanced, i.e. that for each element there is the same number of atoms on the left- and right-hand side: 1 carbon, 4 hydrogen, and 4 oxygen.

A7.text: For each chemical element i, its conservation requirement can be expressed by the mathematical equation ∑j∈reactants aij sj = ∑j∈products aij sj

A8.text: the number of molecules resulting from the reaction can be derived from the principle of conservation of mass, as initially four hydrogen atoms, 4 oxygen atoms and one carbon atom are present (as well as in the final state); thus the number water molecules produced must be exactly two per molecule of carbon dioxide produced

A9.text: Careful experiments were performed in which chemical reactions such as rusting were allowed to take place in sealed glass ampoules; it was found that the chemical reaction did not change the weight of the sealed container and its contents

A10.text: In any chemical reaction, not only is the total mass conserved but also the numbers of atoms of each kind are conserved, and this imposes corresponding constraints on possible values for the stoichiometric coefficients.

A11.text: The number of atoms of a given element X on the reactant side must equal the number of atoms of that element on the product side, whether or not all of those atoms are involved in a reaction.
